ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: that was it
Live virtual lecture and live virtual lab.
All lectures were lived and not recorded.
Some of the class sessions were interactive labs where we would virtually practice the class content.
N/A
virtual labs

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a ton about the human body and it was awesome!
Knowledge on the bone anatomy of the human body
Learning to identify nearly every bone in the body and their features in isolation, as well as a little bit about how to age and sex skeletons.
I generally learned about human osteology (as the course title suggests) and how to identify bones in isolation.
understanding components all the human bones and how they relate to their function, using morphological differences to determine age and sex.
I learned a lot about human skeletal anatomy and musculature.
I learned a great deal about the human skeleton and its associated soft tissues such as muscles and nerves.
A holistic view of the musculoskeletal system. Great class!
Knowledge of all the bones in the body, and their key features, as well as important muscle attachments and nerves

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I love the course! wish i had it in person

Strengths: Taught very well with useful study guides to help guide studying for the quizzes; Fantastic TFs and Professor
Weaknesses: Lacking a 3d component, I wish there was some software where the Professor could have pointed every part out in a 3D format/view of the bone
I thought Professor Sargis and the TFs did the best job they could to provide an engaging learning environment considering the circumstances. I especially enjoyed the format of labs.

I think this course is probably amazing in person but online, it definitely depended a bit on the photos that were included for identifying each structure given. I do think the structure of the course generally makes it accessible to both STEM and non-STEM students.
Dr. Sargis is a wonderful teacher and was great at answering questions. Online lecture sometimes was difficult to engage with, but I feel this is a challenge that comes with online coursework.

A strength of this course was its emphasis on practice before a real assessment. I felt that the labs held before every quiz prepared me to do well in the course. I also enjoyed how much the knowledge learned in the class was framed in terms of practical purposes. As an aspiring doctor, I feel like I have many new skills that will be helpful later in my career.

The biggest weakness was the virtual format, but that's something that couldn't be changed given this semester's circumstances.
Great overview of different bone systems. Compartmentalized in a clear and easy to understand way.
Excellent course, no improvements! Taught in an order of alternating easy & difficult modules to ease students into the class, and modules helped to learn bones in sections of the body one by one.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was the best it could be. Images were really hard to see at times :(

It would have been helpful for students in and around New Haven to have the chance to take home a practice skeleton, but I understand the issues that come with giving that advantage to only some. The 3D model resources were fantastic!
Using online website for virtual studying and visualization of bones was very helpful.
This was an extremely hard course to teach virtually given the nature of bone identification. That being said, I found the virtual skeletons to be pretty helpful in guiding my learning.
N/A

Virtual labs were a great learning experience especially since we could ask questions and access our notes so we could learn while we went. Students without great internet/video access still could ask questions in the chat box without video/volume on, which made the class inclusive.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: yes
YES!
Definitely, if youre interested in learning about the human skeleton and are willing to put in the work to memorize the features!

I would if you are pre-med but as a non-pre-med student, I think that there are science credits that require less memorization than this one and I would push students in the direction of those courses even though I did enjoy Human Osteology.
Yes - the course teaches exactly what is advertised, and the lectures were very detailed and easy to follow.
Yes  its a wonderful class that allows students to learn and engage with material.

Yes, definitely take this class. It's rare to find classes at Yale that satisfy all three benefits of 1.) being intellectually stimulating and useful, 2.) being light on work, and 3.) having a generous grade distribution. Of course you should only take a class if it interests you, but I found those other considerations to be met by this course. I would recommend taking this course when it's offered in person, though.
I would recommend this class to anyone that is interested in going into medicine. It is a great introductory course into looking at the different bones in the body and how they articulate.

Absolutely, if you are interested at all in the human body! Really satisfying to finish the course and realize you know all the bones and their key features, as well as important muscles and nerves, which will be an excellent foundation for learning further anatomy if you want to pursue medicine. Not too rigorous, instructors facilitate learning, virtual labs are engaging, and quizzes were not stressful
